sentences.english: One is the Sun-Dance.

sentences.original: êh-nitotamâht manitôw, kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniw kitaw-ohpikit ôtah askîhk.
sentences.text: ê-nitotamâht manitôw kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniw kita-ohpikit ôta askîhk
sentences.english: The Sun-Dance consists of this, that God is entreated that every human being may grow up and thrive here on this earth.

sentences.original: êwako nipâkwêsimôwin, nîso-kîsikâw pikoh aniki kâ-nîmihitocik nipiy êkâ ê-minihkwêcik, êkwa mîciwin êkâ êh-mîcicik nîso-kîsikâw.
sentences.text: êwako nipâkwêsimôwin nîso-kîsikâw piko aniki kâ-nîmihitocik nipiy êkâ ê-minihkwêcik êkwa mîciwin êkâ ê-mîcicik nîso-kîsikâw
sentences.english: The Sun-Dance consists of this, that for two days and no longer the dancers drink no water and for two days eat no food.

sentences.original: mayaw kâ-pôyihk, sêmâk kahkiyaw kîwâniwiw, ê-ntaw-âtoskêhk.
sentences.text: mayaw kâ-pôyohk sêmâk kahkiyaw kîwâniwiw ê-nitawi-atoskêhk
sentences.english: As soon as it is over, at once all go home and return to work.

sentences.original: namoya wîhkâc êh-kisiwâsihk, êwako mîkiwâhp k-âpacihtâcik nêhiyawak.
sentences.text: namôya wîhkâc ê-kisiwâsihk êwako mîkiwâhp kâ-âpacihtâcik nêhiyawak
sentences.english: It is never in anger that the Cree use this lodge.
That is all.
sentences.footnote: LB: The insistence upon prompt return to work and upon absence of black magic (“it is never in anger”) are, of course, pleas for the dances, some of which have been forbidden by the government. The informant spoke much more freely when notes were not being taken;  when dictating he broke off at frequent intervals with, “That is all.” Then, when reminded of some feature he had left out, he would go on for a while.  This accounts for the form of our text.

sentences.original: pîsim piyêsiw mostos ohtin, êwakonik nêwo k-ôh-nipâkwêsimohk, êh-miyâcik ayîsiyiniwah êwakonik.
sentences.text: pîsim piyêsiw mostos ohtin êwakonik nêwo kâ-ôh-nipâkwêsimohk ê-miyâcik ayîsiyiniwa êwakonik
sentences.english: Sun, Thunderbird, Buffalo, Wind, for these four the Sun-Dance  is danced, since they gave it to man.

sentences.original: manitôw otawâsimisah ê-kîh-wiyâhât kita-nitotamâht pimâtisiwin, êwakonik âcimostawêwak ôhtâwiyiwâwa manitôwah.
sentences.text: manitôw otawâsimisa ê-kî-wihât kita-nitotamâht pimâtisiwin êwakonik âcimostawêwak ôhtâwiyiwâwa manitôwa
sentences.english: Since God appointed these his children, that he might be entreated for life, it is they who convey the message to God their Father.

sentences.original: êkosi êwakô ohci kâ-nipâkwêsimohk; namoya êh-mâyâtahk.
sentences.text: êkosi êwako ohci kâ-nipâkwêsimohk namôya ê-mâyâtahk
sentences.english: This, then, is the purpose of the Sun-Dance; not evil.
In many instances Cree owe their lives to it.

sentences.original: ayis namoya êyakonih piko êh-ntotamôwâcik kit-ôh-pimâtisicik;
sentences.text: ayis namôya êwakoni piko ê-nitotamawâcik kita-ôh-pimâtisicik
sentences.english: But, in fact, it is not only for themselves that they ask for the power to live;

sentences.original: kahkiyaw kitaw-ohpikit ayîsiyiniw ôtah ôm âskiy êy-isi-nitotahkik kâ-nipâkwêsimôwinihkêcik.
sentences.text: kahkiyaw kita-ohpikit ayîsiyiniw ôta ôma askiy ê-isi-nitotahkik kâ-nipâkwêsimôwinihkêcik
sentences.english: that every human being on this earth may thrive is the prayer of them who celebrate the Sun-Dance.

sentences.original: êh-âhkosit awiyak, asotam ta-wîcihiwêt, ta-nîmihitot, manitôwah êh-ntotamôwât.
sentences.text: ê-âhkosit awiyak asotam ta-wîcihiwêt ta-nîmihitot manitôwa ê-nitotamawât
sentences.english: When one is ill, he makes a vow that he will take part in the dance and the prayer to God.

sentences.original: tâpwê âskaw pimâtisiwak êkotah ohci nêhiyawak.
sentences.text: tâpwê âskaw pimâtisiwak êkota ohci nêhiyawak
sentences.english: Truly, often have Cree owed their lives to this.

sentences.original: pîhtwâhêwak êwakonih ôhi kahkiyaw, ôhi pîsimwah mîna piyêsiwah mîna mostoswa mîna ohtinah.
sentences.text: pîhtwâhêwak êwakoni ôhi kahkiyaw ôhi pîsimwa mîna piyêsiwa mîna mostoswa mîna ohtina
sentences.english: They cause each of them to smoke, the Sun and the Thunderbird and the Buffalo and the Wind.
They show them the tobacco.
He who is about to give the Sun-Dance, “Look upon this thing!

sentences.original: kitâpam awah, nôhtâ kisê-manitôw, kitawâsimis êh-wîh-kanawêyihtamawak kita-pîhtwât!
sentences.english: Look upon this tobacco, God, my Father, which I shall keep for Thy child to smoke.

sentences.original: miy sôhkisiwin awa kitawâsimis kâ-kanawêyihtamawak cistêmâwa.
sentences.english: Give power to Thy child for whom I keep the tobacco.
Moderate him, so that mortal men be not frightened by aught.

sentences.original: itah mânokêyâni, kitawâsimisak kâ-wîh-mânokawakik, kita-kitâpahtahkik wîkiwâw taw-okimâwahk êkâ awiyak kitah-âhkosit;
sentences.english: There where I set up the lodge which I am about to erect for Thy children to look upon, let no one be ill;
sentences.footnote: LB on {taw-okimâwahk}: Doubtless error of record.

sentences.original: kahkiyaw kiyâm kita-miywayihtamwak ôki kitawâsimisak, tahtoh kê-pê-ntawâpahkêcik ôma pîsim piyêsiw wîkih kâ-wîh-osîhtâyân, ohtin mîna.
sentences.english: let all Thy children rejoice in it, as many as shall come to look upon this lodge of Sun and Thunderbird which I shall build, and of the Wind.

sentences.original: êyakonik kita-kisêwâtisiwak koyahâkanak, kâ-sôhkahk kipimâcihiwêwin, êwakoh kita-miyihcik kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniwak.
sentences.english: May these Thy appointed creatures be propitious, so that Thy firm gift of life may be given to all men.
When here I stand let them not by aught be frightened.

sentences.original: wâh-pimohtêcih kitawâsimis, pêyahtik kita-pimohtêw awa piyêsiw, nipiy kita-sâpopatât ohcih omâ askiy, êkâ ta-pîkopayik.
sentences.english: When Thy child is about to walk abroad, let this Thunderbird go gently, drenching this earth with rain, that it may not break apart.
Be kind to me; hear me with pity!
Thus do I now speak, that all may live in health.”
That is all of this.

sentences.original: kîspin piyêsiw êh-miyât êwako mîkiwâhp, kâ-mânokêt ayîsiyiniw, mistahi âpacihiwêw.
sentences.text: kîspin piyêsiw ê-miyât êwako mîkiwâhp kâ-mânokêt ayîsiyiniw mistahi âpacihiwêw
sentences.english: If the Thunderbird gives a man this lodge, and he has set it up, he does much good to people.
sentences.footnote: LB: Informant had explained that not anyone, but only he who had been so commanded in a vision by a Thunderer, could give a Sun-Dance.

sentences.original: kahkiyaw awiya âpacihêw, êkâ ta-nôhtêyâpâkwêyit, ta-miyoskâkoyit nipiy.
sentences.text: kahkiyaw awiya âpacihêw êkâ ta-nôhtêyâpâkwêyit ta-miyoskâkoyit nipiy
sentences.english: He does good to each and every one, that they need not thirst and that water may benefit them.
This is why; for the sake of mankind is why one gives a Sundance.
That, then, is all.
Now another.

sentences.original: pêyakwan pîhtwâwin, pêyak tipiskâw pikoh ê-nikamohk, sîsîkwanak êh-âpacihihcik.
sentences.text: pêyakwan pîhtwâwin pêyak tipiskâw piko ê-nikamohk sîsîkwanak ê-âpacihihcik
sentences.english: Of similar nature is the Smoking-Lodge, in which the singing lasts only one night and rattles are used.

sentences.original: pêyak wâkayôs êwako nîkân ê-wîhtamâkêt, nêhiyawah ê-wîhtamawât.
sentences.text: pêyak wâkayôs êwako nîkân ê-wîhtamâkêt nêhiyawa ê-wîhtamawât
sentences.english: It was a certain bear who first told of this, revealing it to the Cree.
It is for these: Sun, Thunderbird, Buffalo.
Somewhere within the lodge lies a stone.

sentences.original: êyakonik êh-miyihcik cistêmâwa, kita-pîhtwâcik, êh-ntotamâhcik pimâtisiwin.
sentences.text: êyakonik ê-miyihcik cistêmâwa kita-pîhtwâcik ê-nitotamâhcik pimâtisiwin
sentences.english: It is they who are given tobacco that they may smoke and are entreated for life.

sentences.original: tâpitâwih pîhcâyihk pîhtwâwikamikohk mîcisonâniwiw, minihkwâniwiw nipiy.
sentences.text: tâpitawi pîhcâyihk pîhtwâwikamikohk mîcisonâniwiw minihkwâniwiw nipiy
sentences.english: But also, within the Smoking-Lodge there is eating, and water is drunk.
Old women erect the Smoking-Lodge, not men.
They do not dance.
Every time they sing, when they have sung their song, they ask them for the gift of life.
As many as sing, all ask them for it.
From time to time within the lodge he weeps who is giving the Smoking-Ceremony.

sentences.original: ôki awâsisak kit-ôhpikiwak miyinân, kit-ôh-ohpikinâwasoyâhk! itwêwak kâ-pîhtwâcik.
sentences.english: “Grant us that these children may grow up, grant us the gift of bringing our children to maturity!” say those who smoke.

sentences.original: tahto mîna kâ-nikamocik, kahkiyaw miyâwak cistêmâwa, tahto kâ-nikamocik.
sentences.text: tahto mîna kâ-nikamocik kahkiyaw miyâwak cistêmâwa tahto kâ-nikamocik
sentences.english: As many, also, as sing, all are given tobacco, as many as sing.
From time to time the women weep.
“Lend a pitying ear to our prayer!

sentences.original: kitimâkêyim ôki nâpêwak, ê-kitimâkisicik, ê-ntotamâkoyêkok pimâtisiwin.
sentences.english: Pity these men, who are pitiable, who implore you for life.

sentences.original: ôki mîna iskwêwak t-ôhpikihêwak otawâsimisiwâwa kitimâkêyiminân, kisê-manitôw!
sentences.english: And that these women, also, may bring their children to maturity, take pity on us, Lord God!

sentences.original: ôki kitawâsimisak kâ-wîci-pîhtwâmihcik miy kit-ôh-kitimâkêyihtahkik kêkway, t-ôhpikîmakaniyik wiyawâw.
sentences.english: To those children who are given part in the smoking, grant, that   they may feel pity for all things, and that their bodies may grow and thrive.
Let not Thy child, the Thunderbird try to frighten us.

sentences.original: mîna ohtin êkâ wiya itah êh-ayât ayîsiyiniw kakwê-sêkihtâ miywâsin kohpikihcikêwin.
sentences.english: Do not with Wind, there where is mortal man, seek to frighten that good thing Thou hast caused to grow up.
Even thus grant us Thy pity!”
That is all.

sentences.original: êh-pôni-mâtocik ôki iskwêwak, pêyak ê-mâtot, hay! itâw, kitatamihin ê-ntotamâkêstamawiyan pimâtisiwin!
sentences.text: ê-pôni-mâtocik ôki iskwêwak pêyak ê-mâtot itâw
sentences.english: When the women cease to weep, when one has wept, “Thanks!” they say to her; “I thank you for praying for me for life!”

sentences.original: êh-itêyimâcik, êh-mâtoyit, pêskis êh-pîkiskwêyit, mâskôc ta-kitimâkihtawâw, êh-itêyihtahkik ôk âyîsiyiniwak, hay! k-ôh-itwêcik.
sentences.text: ê-itêyimâcik ê-mâtoyit pêskis ê-pîkiskwêyit ê-itêyihtahkik ôki ayisiyiniwak kâ-ôh-itwêcik
sentences.english: Because those people think thus concerning her, when she weeps and at the same time speaks her prayer, because they think “Doubtless she will be heard with pity,” that is why they say, “Thanks!”

sentences.original: êkosi êyako pêyak tipiskâw êh-pôyohk, mayaw êh-kîsikâk, sêmâk kahkiyaw kîwêwak ayîsiyiniwak.
sentences.text: êkosi êwako pêyak tipiskâw ê-pôyohk mayaw ê-kîsikâk sêmâk kahkiyaw kîwêwak ayîsiyiniwak
sentences.english: Then, when after that one night the ceremony is closed, as soon as day comes, at once all the people go home.
They take home much food.

sentences.original: mistah kîsitêpôw êwako aniki êh-pîhtwât awiyak, pêyak piko omîciwin kâ-miyât, kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniwah ta-mîciyit.
sentences.text: mistahi kîsitêpôw êwako aniki ê-pîhtwât awiyak pêyak piko omîciwin kâ-miyât kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniwa ta-mîciyit
sentences.english: When anyone of these people thus smokes, he cooks much, for he alone gives them food, that all the people may eat.
As soon as the ceremony is over, all go to their various homes.
That is all of this.
Another dance still: they dance the Masked-Dance.

sentences.original: êkwah mistikohk tâpisiniyiwa mostoswak waskasîwâhk ohci êh-apisîsisicik.
sentences.text: êkwa mistikohk tâpisiniyiwa mostoswak waskasîwâhk ohci ê-apisîsisicik
sentences.english: To a pole are fastened the smallest of the hoofs of buffalo.
sentences.footnote: LB: Or, “small things (animate: rattles?) made of buffalo-hoofs.”

sentences.original: êyakonik pêyak kîsikâw êh-kîsikâyik piko êh-nîmihitocik.
sentences.text: êyakonik pêyak kîsikâw ê-kîsikâyik piko ê-nîmihitocik
sentences.english: These dancers dance one day, only during daylight.
All wear a headgear.
Their faces are not visible;
holes are cut in their headgear, through which they may see.
This, too, is of the same nature, the Windigo-Dance.

sentences.original: êyakô pêyakwan : tahki mîcisôwak; pisisik nâpêwak, namoya iskwêwak.
sentences.text: êwako pêyakwan tahki mîcisôwak pisisik nâpêwak namôya iskwêwak
sentences.english: This is alike in both: they always eat; there are only men, not women.

sentences.original: pêyakwan mîn êyakô pâh-pêyak piko kâ-miyihcik ayîsiyiniwak, êyako nîmihitôwin, namoya waniyaw, pêyak piko nâpêw.
sentences.text: pêyakwan mîna êwako pâh-pêyak piko kâ-miyihcik ayîsiyiniwak êwako nîmihitôwin namôya waniyaw pêyak piko nâpêw
sentences.english: This, too, is a common feature, that only certain individuals are given the gift of holding this dance; not anybody, but only this or that man.

sentences.original: âskaw nisto-mitanaw nîsitanaw nê-mitanaw ihtasiwak ôki kâ-wîhtikôh-kânisimocik.
sentences.text: âskaw nisto-mitanaw nîsitanaw nêwomitanaw ihtasiwak ôki kâ-wîhtikôh-kânisimocik
sentences.english: Sometimes the Windigo-Dancers were as many as thirty, twenty, or forty in number.

sentences.original: êyakonik êh-asotahkik kitaw-ohci-pimâtisicik, wâhyaw êh-ayâyit owâhkomâkaniwâwa.
sentences.text: êyakonik ê-asotahkik kita-ohci-pimâtisicik wâhyaw ê-ayâyit owâhkômâkaniwâwa
sentences.english: They promised to hold it that they might derive life from it, when their kinsfolk were far away.
“God, let me see my kinsfolk, Thy children.
Then I shall give them a dance.
If I look upon him who laments in sickness, let him live.
By this lodge I shall take my seat.
I shall make the people dance,” he said.
Then truly the others would live.
That is the end of this.
Of old, like soldiers were the Cree.
They did not act without general consent.

sentences.original: mayaw onîmihitôwak, êyakonik pisisik nâpêwak kayâs, kîspin onîmihitôwak, namoya ka-mâcînâwâw; namoya ka-mâcîw awiyak, kîspin êkosi êh-itwêcik, awiyak miyâcîci, mênahoci, ôki onîmihitôwak, âtah, kîmôc nitôtên, êtêyihtahkih awa kâ-mâcît, têpiskâyiki, têkosihkih, wiyâpahkih pêhtamwak onîmihitôwak.
sentences.text: mayaw onîmihitôwak êyakonik pisisik nâpêwak kayâs kîspin onîmihitôwak kîspin êkosi ê-itwêcik awiyak miyâcîci mênahoci ôki onîmihitôwak âta êtêyihtahki awa kâ-mâcît têpiskâyiki têkosihki wiyâpahki pêhtamwak onîmihitôwak
sentences.english: As soon as these dancers, - they were only men, of old, - as soon as these dancers said, “You are not to hunt; no one is to hunt,” then, if anyone hunted and killed game, then these dancers, even though that hunter would think, “I am doing it in secret,” when at night he has arrived, in the morning those dancers would hear it.
Early in the morning they would go forth; they would whoop; they sang.
Then they tore up his belongings.

sentences.original: awa kâ-kîh-mâcît wîkih yâyikisamwân, misiwê êh-pîkosamoht.
sentences.text: awa kâ-kî-mâcît wîki yâyikisamwân misiwê ê-pîkosamoht
sentences.english: The tent of the one who had hunted would be cut into strips, and all his property cut up.
His gun would be taken from him.
“You see, friends, my children are hungry; that is why I have transgressed against you.
Do you keep this tobacco to smoke.

sentences.original: iyikohk kîh-nêwo-tipiskâk, êkospi kika-miyitinâwâw isi-miywêyihtamêk, itwêw awa nâpêw.
sentences.english: In four nights I shall give you that which will please you,” said that man.
When the fourth night had come, he clubbed his dog to death; he killed his dog.
He set it to boil, and the dancers were sent for, that they might partake of it.

sentences.original: kâ-kîs-asamihtwâwi ôk ônîmihitôwak, êkwah, hâw, awa kâ-kî-pîkoswâyahk, nikwêmêsitik, namoya kikisiwâhânaw.
sentences.english: When the dancers had been given it to eat, then, “Now, he whose belongings we have cut to pieces, friends, we have not angered him.

sentences.original: miyihk apasoyah, mîkiwâhp; mîn ayôwinisah miyihk.
sentences.english: Give him tent-poles and a tipi; give him also clothes.”

sentences.original: hâ, êkwah kahkiyaw onîmihitôwak miyêwak t-âpacihtâyit, pâskisikan môsasiniyah mîkiwâhp apasoyah.
sentences.text: hâ êkwa kahkiyaw onîmihitôwak miyêwak ta-âpacihtâyit pâskisikan môsasiniya mîkiwâhp apasoya
sentences.english: Then all the dancers would give him things to use, a gun, bullets, a tipi, lodge-poles.

sentences.original: êkos îsi miyâw, kîspin êkâya kisiwâsit.
sentences.text: êkosi isi miyâw kîspin êkâya kisiwâsit
sentences.english: With such things he was presented, if he did not get angry.

sentences.original: mâk âwa kâ-kisiwâhiht, wîkih êh-pîkosamoht, nama kêkway miyâw.
sentences.text: mâka awa kâ-kisiwâhiht wîki ê-pîkosamoht nama kêkway miyâw
sentences.english: But one who was made angry by the destruction of his dwelling, was not given anything.

sentences.original: tâpwê piko kitimâkisiw, kahkiyaw êh-pîkonamoht otayânah otayôwinisah opâskisikan.
sentences.text: tâpwê piko kitimâkisiw kahkiyaw ê-pîkonamoht otayâna otayiwinisa opâskisikan
sentences.english: He was indeed reduced to misery, what with the tearing up of all his implements, his clothes, and his gun.
That is all.
And another; Little Lousy Fellows the dancers were called.

sentences.original: kâkikê wîkiwâw cimatêyiw pîhtêyis, mîkiwâhp, êyakonik onîmihitôwak.
sentences.text: kâkikê wîkiwâw cimatêyiw pîhtêyas mîkiwâhp êyakonik onîmihitôwak
sentences.english: Their lodge stood permanently in the center of the camp, the lodge of these dancers.

sentences.original: ôki mîna kotakak sîsîkwanisak isiyîhkâsôwak onîmihitôwak.
sentences.text: ôki mîna kotakak sîsîkwanisak isiyîhkâsôwak onîmihitôwak
sentences.english: And another society of dancers was called the Little Rattles.
They danced by daylight.
They were all men.
The women made the chorus as they sang.
And another society, the Big Dogs.
They were men only.

sentences.original: pêyakwan êkos îsi nîmihitôwak, iskwêwa êh-nikamoyit; namoya êh-nîmihitoyit.
sentences.text: pêyakwan êkosi isi nîmihitôwak iskwêwa ê-nikamoyit namôya ê-nîmihitoyit
sentences.english: They danced in the same way, the women singing, but not dancing.
They were all men.
Another society of dancers was called the Partridges.
They did like the preceding.
If anyone killed a buffalo, his possessions were torn up.

sentences.original: ôki kahkiyaw kâ-wîhakik onîmihitôwak pîhtêyas êh-wîkicik, êh-wîhkwêstêkih mîkiwâhpah.
sentences.text: ôki kahkiyaw kâ-wîhakik onîmihitôwak pîhtêyas ê-wîkicik ê-wîhkwêstêki mîkiwâhpa
sentences.english: All these dancers whom I have named, had their lodge in the center, where the other tipis stood in a circle round about.

sentences.original: êyakô kahkiyaw pêyakwan êyako wêyasowêwin, nam âwiya kita-mâcît, asêyas piko kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniw ta-mâcît;
sentences.text: êwako kahkiyaw pêyakwan êwako wiyasiwêwin nama awiya kita-mâcît asêyas piko kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniw ta-mâcît
sentences.english: They all had the same rule, that no one was to hunt, except when all hunted in a band;
that was the law of the dancers.

sentences.original: kîksêpâ pêyak wîhtam, êh-papâ-têpwêt : êkos îtwêwak onîmihitôwak, êh-itwêt aw âyîsiyiniw, êh-wîhtamôwât kahkiyaw âwiya.
sentences.text: kîkisêpâ pêyak wîhtam ê-papâ-têpwêt ê-itwêt awa ayîsiyiniw ê-wîhtamawât kahkiyaw awiya
sentences.english: Early in the morning one would announce it, going about and crying, “So and so say the dancers,” announcing it to every one.
That is all.

sentences.original: anohc pîtos nîmihitôwin, êh-mîcisohk, kahkiyaw, awâsisak, iskwêwak, kahkiyaw êh-itohtatahk mîciwin, ayâpisîs pêyak askihkohk piko.
sentences.text: anohc pîtos nîmihitôwin ê-mîcisohk kahkiyaw awâsisak iskwêwak kahkiyaw ê-itohtatahk mîciwin ayâpisîs pêyak askihkohk piko
sentences.english: Today the dancing is different; there is eating. Everyone, children and women, bring food, each one a small amount, in a kettle.
In the end there is a good amount of food in the tent.

sentences.text: namôya pêyak tipiskâw nôhtaw ê-âpihtâwi-tipiskâk poyonâniwa
sentences.english: Not one night; they stop before midnight.
sentences.footnote: LB: This last is no doubt the “pow-wow”, Cree {pîcicîwak}, literally, “they attract”. An old time dance described by Coming-Day but not mentioned in our text, was the Pole-Dance, {awatâhtikwêwak}, literally, “they carry sticks”.  Sticks were set up upright in the ground, four ropes attached to each, and each rope held by a dancer. The dancers were on horseback, two young men and two young women riding around each stick. Another feature not in this text is the form of the lodge:  the Smoking-Lodge is conical, shaped like an ordinary tipi; the Sun-Dance lodge is straight upright (in a circle) and has a conical top.
